thread.title: DEAL OR NO DEAL: Say goodbye to those sweet ‘mate’s rates’
thread.title_full: DEAL OR NO DEAL: Say goodbye to those sweet ‘mate’s rates’

title: DEAL OR NO DEAL: Say goodbye to those sweet ‘mate’s rates’
text:
Share on Twitter 
DONALD Trump reportedly blasting Malcolm Turnbull before abruptly hanging up on him showed there would be no more “mates rates” between the two countries. 
The ensuing fallout from the 25-minute phone call also indicates the refugee deal between Australia and the US hangs in the balance. 
That is the view of Dougal Robinson, research fellow at the United States Studies Centre at the University of Sydney, who was commenting on the implications of the tense call between the two leaders. 
As revealed by the Washington Post , the US President reportedly blasted Mr Turnbull during their conversation which took place last Saturday saying “this was the worst call by far” . 
Angered at having to honour the refugee deal with Australia brokered by Barack Obama, Mr Trump blew up at Mr Turnbull over the agreement, complaining that he was “going to get killed” politically. 
Mr Robinson said the release of such an exchange between two staunch allies was unprecedented. 
“This (exchange) shows there will be no more mates rates in Australia’s dealings with Washington,” Mr Robinson said. Mr Trump, pictured on the phone to Mr Turnbull on Saturday as National Security Adviser Michael Flynn, left, and chief political strategist Steve Bannon, right, sit nearby. Picture: Pete Marovich/Consolidated News Photos/CNP Source: Supplied 
“Australia has had very good relationship with US Presidents for decades, whether it was Democrat or Republican, Liberal or Labor. 
“This call indicates real change.” 
As the fallout from the call grew, Mr Robinson said we could no longer take a rosy view on the strong US/Australia relationship which Mr Trump would now be viewing as “transactional”. 
“It is clear Trump takes a transactional approach to his allies, including with Australia,” he said. 
Mr Robinson said it would have left Mr Turnbull in a difficult position as details about conversations between high level leaders were kept confidential and private. But he acknowledged it didn’t look good for either of them. 
“It puts everyone in difficult position, there’s no doubt about that,” he said. 
“From Mr Turnbull’s side it raises serious questions about whether the refugee deal will go ahead.” 
Mr Trump labelling Mr Turnbull’s call “the worst” even after speaking with Russian President Vladimir Putin on the same day, would not have sat well with Mr Trump’s opponents, Mr Robinson said. 
“That is extraordinary and this would not have happened between John Howard and George W Bush, or any other leaders” he said. Mr Trump spoke with Mr Turnbull for 25 minutes before hanging up. Picture: Mandel Ngan Source: AFP 
Mr Robinson said all indications appeared to show the leaking of the tense phone call came from the White House itself. 
During a press conference in Melbourne this afternoon, Mr Turnbull said he would not be commenting on what took place during the call. 
But the PM said he would stick up for Australia in public and in private. 
“I’m not going to comment on a conversation between myself and the President of the United States, other than what we have said publicly,” he told reporters in Melbourne. 
“You can surely understand the reasons for that ... it’s better that these things, these conversations are conducted candidly, frankly, privately.” 
‘DEAL IN THE BALANCE’ 
While details of the deal between the two countries has been major news in Australia, few Americans would have taken an interest but the news of the call details would have changed that. 
Just today the POTUS tweeted the deal was dumb and he would be looking into it. Do you believe it? The Obama Administration agreed to take thousands of illegal immigrants from Australia. Why? I will study this dumb deal! — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 2, 2017 
“The Washington Post story, a leading US newspaper, would have pushed this issue (refugee deal) into the domestic debate and that makes it more difficult to see how it will proceed,” Mr Robinson said. 
This deal would not be well received by those who had propelled Mr Trump into power, particularly given he was so vocal about immigration during his campaign, he added. 
Mr Robinson said such a deal was not binding which was why Mr Turnbull would have been keen to seek assurances from Mr Trump that it would still go ahead. 
Given the executive order was signed just a day before the call took place, Mr Trump would also have been angered that he was backed into a corner over accepting refugees from Nauru and Manus Island. 
“His supporters and those behind this executive order would have been somewhat aggrieved,” Mr Robinson said. 
“Enabling this deal would be breaking face with those who propelled him into the presidency. 
“This indicates the deal is less likely to go ahead.” 
However there remains confusion as to whether the US President intends to honour the deal with the White House confirming in a written statement to the ABC that Mr Trump was “still considering” whether to take refugees from Australia. 
Mr Trump later tweeted calling it a “dumb deal” that he would study. Mr Turnbull said details of the weekend’s conversation with Donald Trump were private. Picture: Joe Castro/AAP Source: AAP 
‘TRUMP DOESN’T CARE’ 
White House Bureau Chief at The Washington Post Philip Rucker told the ABC that Mr Trump “doesn’t really care so much that Australia is an ally over many, many years”. 
“The thing you have to understand about Donald Trump is that he is not a natural diplomat, he is not a politician,” he said. 
“He has a career in real estate, in business and deal-making, and he ran for President as somebody who was going to disrupt the world order.” 
Mr Ruckner said the US President was going to make changes and disrupt what he sees as a new world order that’s failing the world. 
“And so he doesn’t really care so much that Australia is an ally over many, many years,” he said. 
“What he cares about is the refugee policy that he views as dangerous for the United States. So he didn’t let diplomatic niceties get in the way of how he felt about that refugee policy.” 
TREAT WITH ‘ALLIES WITH RESPECT’ 
Opposition leader Bill Shorten said it was time Mr Turnbull told Australians what was really going on surrounding the deal. 
Mr Shorten also said he has previously expressed concerns about some of Mr Trump’s views. 
Speaking in Canberra, Mr Shorten said the American alliance should be stronger than individuals. 
“But it is most important that whoever is in power in Canberra or in the White House, that we treat our allies with respect,” he said. 
“If I was Prime Minister, I would want the United States to be our ally, and I’m sure that the Americans want Australia to be their ally, but if I was Prime Minister I would never just be a satellite of the United States.” 
Mr Shorten also said he felt it was important that Australia spoke its mind. 
“I’m not going to make a habit of commenting on every in and out of American politics and I would expect the Americans to respect that about Australian politics,” he said. 
“But sometimes silence can be bad as agreement, and I think it is important that Australia takes a robust, pro-Australian position in its dealing with the United States.”
